instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fashes
threads.message:
a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> The voltage on the back light booster <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> gradually drops from 33v to 8v.
the logic board turns on after 2 second turns of and than turn on ans stays on.
any suggestion?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fashes
threads.message:
Check XW7720 and FB solder under <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>...
<RESISTOR>R5490</RESISTOR> is OK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fashes
threads.message: Dear maybe it's a silly question but there is no XW7720 on the board between <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and L7701.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fashes
threads.message:
Is just a trace, near L7701.
It gets corroded many times...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fashes
threads.message: Thanks for your replay on <RESISTOR>R5490</RESISTOR> 1 and 2 have 8.6v but 3and 4 nothing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fashes
threads.message:
Did you change <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>?
Be sure it is properly soldered...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fashes
threads.message:
no sir i haven't replace the <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> yet
Should I do it?
it lights up when it chimes and than the voltage on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> gradually drops to 8.5 which is my ppbus-G3h.
